displayed_text: Patient: …W____ I’ll - I can be on a plane. I can drive it… Doctor: Okay. Okay. Patient: …in nine hours, in - I can drive it in thirteen hours it’s not a big deal. Doctor: Let’s work on that scheduling so I just want to recap so we’re straight… Patient: Yep. Doctor: …and then you tell me if this, actually you tell me, you tell me what I just said so that we’re straight. What’s our plan? Patient: Our plan is we’re gonna, we’re gonna probably we’re gonna go and we’re gonna go to radiation onc - uh radiation I’m gonna say oncology. Doctor: Radiology. Patient: Radiology well, okay. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. Patient: And we’re gonna go and we’re gonna go find that uh that two centimeter uh mass. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: - is open for discussion is to treat this as if it was a prostate cancer and see if it goes away. Patient: Okay, so - Doctor: And if it does, and in retrospect, because if we give you a hormone therapy, for example and it’s a gist, it will not increase sized at all. Patient: Correct. Doctor: If it’s a hormone therapy and it’s prostate cancer, you know it’s gonna disappear or decrease by ninety percent within the first few months. Patient: Okay, would that be your recommendation, to do more hormonal? Doctor: Well, I was gonna, I was gonna talk to you about that. Um… Patient: Right. Doctor: I think it it probably - some type of hormone therapy is probably gonna be in your near future. It might not be the immediate future, but I think sooner rather than later given that we’ve tried this sort of outside-the-box non-hormonal type of therapy and it hasn’t really you know worked as well as we had hoped, the next step I think given that the PSA is rising and given that this lymph node is increasing, I do happen to believe it’s prostate cancer would lead me to the conclusion that hormone therapy is probably the next best thing to do. Patient: Now with hormonal therapy, um it is not a cure. It’s just a uh–. Doctor: That’s correct… It’s - Patient: Okay, so it’s not a cure. The only thing it would be doing is slowing down the progress of the, it would slow down the -

Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know? We, we have a look now which is not a super early look but it still is within, you know, a few weeks of finishing. Sometimes when times goes on, then, you know, you’ll have new stuff, but- Family Member: So no, no, no, uh, MRIs in order right now? Doctor: No. Unless you’re telling me you’re worse. Family Member: Well, he’s got, he’s in pain, but that might be sciatic. He don’t know. Patient: No. Doctor: Man, it’s always your darn back. Family Member: Well, hip and leg. Doctor: Is it the hip and leg? Patient: Well, it’s, it like radiates from here down. Family Member: The pelvis down. Doctor: Uh, refresh my memory. Have we ever MRI’d that?

Family Member: Is that good for him to be taking? Doctor: Yeah. No. You’re on a medicine that interacts with everything known to mankind. XTANDI is, remember we talked about how it’s processed through the liver? So it’d be good if you don’t add on extra stuff that will tax your liver that would make the XTANDI either work less or more. More is not necessarily better, and it might make you have more side effects. Family Member: Have you heard of fluorescence? Doctor: Never heard of it. But in general we try to stay away from too many supplements on drugs like XTANDI because it is a known interactor Family Member: Oh. Oh. It’s not a drug. It’s like a homeopathic. Doctor: of many existing drugs. You have to be careful. Right. But all of those are drugs. They really are. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: However you want to bill it and put it in a nice package, anything you take is a potential drug swirling around in your bloodstream. Family Member: Hm Mmm. Doctor: How much, how little, we don’t know. So at the moment, while you’re on other treatment, I wouldn’t advise it. Okay? Family Member: It could nullify the treatment? Doctor: Yeah. Or make it worse.

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, there’s a, there’s a couple of trials that are in the works that might be specifically suited for you Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because of this mutation. Patient: So, we’re not, not doing standard of care. Doctor: Right. Patient: Pat We’re looking at potent—very, uh, plausibly potential choices down the road. Doctor: Yes. Patient: And, and, and so at this point --- Doctor: I mean, including standard of care. So, standard of care is always our baseline. Patient: Right. Doctor: And then we, you know, I could just, my description will be, “here’s what standard of care does, here’s what we expect.”

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.disagree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::disagree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: To go to Cornell. Doctor: Cornell or UCLA, so, yeah. Patient: Well, I guess I would ask you, if possible, to check out both avenues. I’d want to see which one. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I mean my interest, our interest, is just to stop this stuff from growing. It seems to be growing at a consistent pace. I don’t know if it’s slow, fast, or whatever, but it’s not stopping. And do you think that this, this sort of, from what you know from this, from the, you know PSMA, that would have a real uh opportunity to stop the growth? Doctor: Yeah. I think from the data they published, it actually looks really good, uh, and- Patient: If it’s so good, why don’t they, why does it take so long in the U.S. then to get these? Doctor: So, in Germany, and Australia, I know they’re also doing it in Australia. I know it’s a little farther for you- Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Uh in Germany they have a law that if the doctor thinks something is beneficial it doesn’t have to be you know like you know in America, FDA approved. So the FDA, the bar is show me it makes people live longer. It’s a pretty high bar. Because that requires a lot of patients, a lot time. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but at the end of the day, you feel really confident that what I’m giving you could help.

Patient: Well, I mean- Doctor: Yeah. Patient: -at least we’re going to get them all. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: But I mean - I don’t know. Doctor: Yeah, you just need to know where he wants to put the Patient: I can give you his contact information. Doctor: Yeah, I mean he’s at B___, right? Is it at B___ – L__ at B___? Patient: I think he’s at B___ or some other. Yeah, I’m not getting the radiation. Doctor: Is he T____? Patient: No, I might have some contact information. Doctor: Uh, okay it’s like K_ (spells name)

Patient: In three months I’ll get another CAT scan? Doctor: Yes. Patient: But not bone scan? Doctor: No I don’t think we need it unless anything changes with your surgery and all the symptoms – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - and of course if any of that changes, don’t wait the three months. I need to know before that of course. Patient: Yeah right. Family Member: Okay, getting back to the bone scan. Doctor: Yes. Family Member: What about osteoporosis? Is that showing up? Something we need to be concerned about? Doctor: No bone scan typically doesn’t show up. Family Member: Oh, okay.

Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Right. Healthcare Professional: Alright. Doctor: So let’s do that, see how you do and then we’ll switch, we’ll add the sleeping pill. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay because too many changes if the pills don’t match well together. Patient: Well I wouldn’t take them all at one time nowhere, if I take my other pill then I wait another hour and then I take that. Doctor: Okay. Well you definitely cannot take the Ambien and the Restoril together. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Are you going to remember that? Patient: Don’t take the Ambien and the who again?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: But you know I never just do the standard routine anything. (Laughs) Patient: I been here long enough, I just, I am not new here. Doctor: Yes. So there is uh you know the trial is two-thirds of the people get vitamin C, Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: high dose. So this stuff comes out of Hopkins you know from a special company. It took us forever to do it. But the grade of vitamin C is great. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Because they’re not all the same. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so you always fuss about that. Because there’s other people giving high-dose vitamin C Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but you can’t guarantee the product.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: it was like oh, no you kind of had these bits and pieces, Patient: Right. Doctor: one, your insurance won’t approve it and number two it’s the wrong treatment. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, if that’s sort of gone and nowhere to be found on this CAT scan then I think radium is it. Now, radium does two things. One is that it helps you live longer but also helps with pain so those people who are, you know, whether you’re taking a Tylenol over-the-counter or you’re taking actual narcotics that should improve. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you know, all the new studies are like hey, radium and phone a friend, you know, radium and Xtandi, radium and chemo, radium and whatever. So, they’re all in studies but not standard of care yet. I’m gonna pause right there and see how you guys are doing. This is not a test. There’s no test. No test. Family Member: Okay, he was asking when we were waiting for you. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: If the treatment you’re going to give him is going to make him feel better Patient: Yes. Family Member: or is he still gonna feel fatigued and miserable.

Patient: Oh, of course. Doctor: You know, so we want you to be ready. What I want is for that to be in your medicine cabinet. Family Member 1: If his gums are sensitive, can I call M___ too? Doctor: Yep, yes. And you know you could gargle with salt water to just keep that bacteria moving out of there. So there's no sort of overdose on warm saltwater. Family Member 1: How about hydrogen peroxide, diluted? Doctor: That's hard. Family Member 1: Oh okay. Doctor: See that's hard because any alcohol based products for our mouths are bad. Family Member 1: There’s alcohol, I forgot. Doctor: So it's a challenge for cancer patients. So like if you look at Listerine or Crest they have now the non alcohol version. So you could try that. Family Member 1: He likes to gargle with Listerine. Doctor: Yeah, there's a non alcohol version of Listerine.

Healthcare Professional: You had one, oh yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Yeah, that’s what my daughter has taken. It’s pretty old. It still runs great. Family Member: She can’t walk out the front door and be on the same level as you know. She’d got to go down a little bit before she can come back. Doctor: Oh my gosh! Family Member: every kid needs thinking they’re going to change. Doctor: Yeah, no I wouldn’t give them new cars anyway. Patient: That’s normal to buy a new car, yeah. Doctor: Who wants to pay that insurance, too? Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, so now we will probably move you guys to Wednesday, Tuesday or Wednesday. Which day would you prefer? Family Member: You pick. Patient: Wednesday’s fine.

Patient: I threw up times. I have Doctor: I think we should refer him to GI because I really don’t know what uh… Patient: What? Doctor: I have no idea. I’ve never seen that. Patient: Yeah me either. Doctor: And we can’t see it on the CAT scan either. So I don’t know what to make of it. Patient: What? Doctor: We’ll, we’ll talk to the radiologist. Patient: Wait a minute, wait a minute Dr. B____, you got me scared and everything. If I can’t see it on the CAT scan. Doctor: Why are you scared? Patient: I’m not well well God is good. Doctor: It’s a good thing. Patient: Yes.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: It may potentially lessen the side effects if you do it that way without the Lupron at the same time. Patient: Yeah, yeah. For some reason the Lupron, that just knocks me out. For some reason I forget a lot of things, hallucination; I get a Doctor: Great, now when would you like to check the next PSA level and when would you like to do it? Patient: Now next PSA, now did you place an order for mine? Doctor: I did. Patient: Okay, because when I went there they said they didn’t see it. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And I had to call in and they faxed it. Doctor: Okay. I will do two things today. When I place the prescription I will send electronically and then I will also print the actual paper prescription. Patient: Okay. Uh huh. Doctor: And hand it to you. That should be the backup.
